entry.title: Electronic Document Processing for Italy: Avoid Issues During Migration from Neo to Cloud Foundry
entry.content:
Title image for the topic of avoiding issues during migration of your system from Neo to Cloud Foundry environment

Migrating your system from Neo environment to Cloud Foundry environment to continue using electronic document processing for Italy after 2025 can be a complex process, especially when dealing with custom domains and Cloud Integration tenant applications. One critical prerequisite that often poses challenges is ensuring that both test and production tenants are on the same system landscape. 

Here you find what you need to know to prepare for what you can do to make this process smoother. 

Understanding Landscapes 

A landscape refers to the environment where your applications and services are hosted. It can be a normal landscape or an extension landscape. To determine if your tenant is on an extension landscape, check the URL. For instance, a URL like "https://tenantname.cfapps.eu10-003.hana.ondemand.com/itspaces" indicates an extension landscape due to the "-003" in the URL. For more information, see Extension Landscapes. 

Importance of Matching System Landscapes 

For a successful setup, both the custom domain and cloud integration tenant must reside on the same landscape. If they aren't on the same landscape, the setup fails. This requires you to work on an additional step of reprovisioning the tenants. For example, a mismatch occurs if the custom domain is on the cf-eu12 landscape while the tenant is on the cf-eu12-001 landscape. 

Mitigating Risks 

To minimize the risk of mismatched landscapes, you should request a test and a production tenant simultaneously. This approach reduces the chance of being provisioned to different extension landscapes. Before developing any content, it's crucial to verify that the domains of both tenants align. 

By taking these precautions, you can ensure a smoother migration process and avoid unnecessary complications. Remember, a little foresight can save a lot of time and effort down the road. 

Steps for Migration 

You can find more information about how to migrate electronic document processing for Italy FatturaPA and B2B from Neo to Cloud Foundry environment on SAP Note 2583309. 

 

Thanks for reading! 

Got any questions or feedback? Please leave a comment below or give feedback about the product assistance directly on the SAP Help Portal by using the comments feature. 

 

See you next time, 

Ailane Kuhn

entry.title: Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping
entry.content:
Businesses require customization to meet their unique needs. If you use the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you can add custom fields to support fiscal , providing enhanced flexibility for you.

What’s New?

This feature allows you to add custom fields to the fiscal document structure of supported documents using the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping (NFE_CLOUD_EXTENSIBILITY) Business Add-In (BAdI).

This BAdI enables the addition of simple and complex data types (fields, structures and tables) at any point within the document structure, ensuring effective handling of dynamic data. This functionality is available for cloud landscapes, via Developer Extensibility, supported by ABAP for Cloud Development. 

Supported Documents

Currently, NF-e (Electronic Nota Fiscal), NFS-e (Electronic Service Nota Fiscal, specifically for São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro), and CT-e (Electronic Transportation Document) are supported.

Known Restrictions: You can add custom fields and structures using the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping BAdI. However, you can't change the data already provided by SAP. Note that the new fields or structures you add only appear in the XML file if the Electronic Nota Fiscal (NFe) Authorize, Electronic Service Nota Fiscal (NFSe) and CTe Autorize APIs already support them.

Implementing the Business Add-In

The IF_NFE_CLOUD_EXTENSIBILITY interface is composed of the Add Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping (ADD_FIELDS) method, which returns the ADDITIONAL_FIELDS parameter containing a structure with the new fields added to the end of the segment being processed.  

  • IV_DOCNUM: The document number that allows selecting document data from the Brazil Nota Fiscal Document Data CDS view.
  • ID_DOCUMENT: The structure of the document sent for approval.
  • IV_BR_NFECLOUDEXTNMODEL: The type of electronic document being processed (NF-e, NFS-e or CT-e ).
  • IA_SEGMENT: The segment data of the document for which you’re creating the implementation.
  • IV_SEGMENT_PATH: The path of the segment being processed.
  • CD_ADDITIONAL_FIELDS: The structure that returns the new fields added to the document.

Filters

For performance improvements and easy implementation, the Extension Fields for Nota Fiscal Mapping  BAdI has two filters:

  • Segment Filter (IV_SEGMENT_PATH): specifies the full path of the segment in the structure. For example, for the header segment, the IV_SEGMENT_PATH is "$.HEADER". Each document has a different root segment for the path of the structure being processed:
    • NF-e: J_1BNFE_S_AUTHORIZE_400
    • CT-e: NFE_CLOUD_CTE_MAP_AUTHORIZE
    • NFS-e RJ: IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE
    • NFS-e SP: IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE_SP
  •  NFe Cloud Extension Model (IV_BR_NFECLOUDEXTNMODEL): cloud extension model for which the BAdI implementation will be called. This parameter includes the NFe and NFSe filter values.

Known Restrictions: Currently, only NFS-e documents from São Paulo and Rio de Janeiro are supported.

Prerequisites

You have connected to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud system in ADT (Eclipse-based ABAP development tools) and you're assigned to the DEVELOPER role.

How to Implement

You can create BAdI implementations through developer extensibility, which depends on filters.

1. Go to ABAP Development Tools (ADT) and create your own package. Make sure your package starts with Z in your namespace.

2. Create a new Transport Request for your package.

3. Choose the ABAP for Cloud Development Language Version.

4. Select the package you created, then choose New and Other ABAP Repository Object.

5. Select BAdI Enhancement Implementation and choose Next.

6. Enter a name that starts with the letter Z and if needed also your previously created package and find the Enhancement Spot that holds the released implementation.

7. Assign your BAdI Enhancement Implementation to an existing transport request, then the screen for the BAdI Enhancement Implementation appears.

8. Browse the BAdI you want to implement and enter a name for the implementation (starting with Z) and choose Add. 

This BAdI filters by segment path and model, allowing you to create separate implementations for each segment you need to extend.

Examples

Check the following examples on how you can structure your paths: 

  • Header of structure J_1BNFE_S_AUTHORIZE_400: PATH = "$.HEADER"
  • Issuer Address inside structure NFE_CLOUD_CTE_MAP_AUTHORIZE: "$.DOCUMENT_INFO.ISSUER.ADDRESS"
  • Prestador inside structure IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE: "$.INFRPS.PRESTADOR"
  • Endereço Tomador inside structure IF_J_1BNFSE_TYPES=>TY_AUTHORIZE_SP: "$.RPS.ENDERECOTOMADOR"

This enhancement empowers you to tailor  your documentation processes to better fit your operational needs.

Have you found this blog post useful? If so, choose “like” (kudos), share it with your colleagues, and follow me for similar content.

You are welcome to leave your questions and read similar blog posts on the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance SAP Community. Remember to follow the SAP Electronic Invoicing for Brazil (SAP Nota Fiscal Eletronica) and the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance community tags to keep up with the latest NF-e news.

Thank you, and until next time,

Luize

entry.title: Step-by-Step Implementation Guide: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance (DRC) Cash Flow Statements
entry.content:
Cash flow statements are one of the three fundamental financial statements that every business must prepare, alongside the income statement and balance sheet. While the income statement shows profitability and the balance sheet displays financial position, the cash flow statement reveals the actual cash movements in and out of your business. Understanding how to prepare and interpret cash flow statements—and choosing between the direct and indirect methods—is crucial for effective financial management.

This comprehensive guide includes detailed video tutorials to walk you through every aspect of implementing SAP DRC-based cash flow statements, from initial setup to advanced configuration and real-world examples.

 

1. What is a Cash Flow Statement?

A cash flow statement tracks the actual cash receipts and payments during a specific period, categorized into three main activities:

  • Operating Activities: Cash flows from core business operations
  • Investing Activities: Cash flows from buying/selling long-term assets
  • Financing Activities: Cash flows from debt, equity, and dividend transactions

The statement answers a critical question: "Where did our cash come from, and where did it go?"

1.1 The Two Methods: Direct vs. Indirect

The accounting standards allow two approaches for presenting the operating activities section of the cash flow statement:

The Indirect Method

The indirect method starts with net income and adjusts for non-cash items and changes in working capital to arrive at operating cash flow.

Typical Indirect Method Structure:

Net Income                            $100,000
Adjustments:
  Depreciation                        $20,000
  Increase in Accounts Receivable     ($15,000)
  Decrease in Inventory               $10,000
  Increase in Accounts Payable        $8,000
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Indirect Method:

  • Easier to prepare from existing financial statements
  • Less expensive to implement
  • Shows the relationship between net income and cash flow

Disadvantages:

  • Doesn't show actual cash receipts and payments
  • Less useful for cash flow forecasting
  • More difficult for users to understand actual cash movements

The Direct Method

The direct method reports actual cash receipts and payments from operating activities, showing gross cash flows.

Typical Direct Method Structure:

Cash Receipts:
  From customers                      $500,000
  From interest and dividends         $5,000
Cash Payments:
  To suppliers                        ($200,000)
  To employees                        ($150,000)
  For interest                        ($10,000)
  For taxes                           ($22,000)
Net Cash from Operating Activities    $123,000

Advantages of Direct Method:

  • Shows actual cash transactions
  • More intuitive and easier to understand
  • Better for cash flow forecasting

Disadvantages:

  • More expensive and complex to implement
  • Requires detailed tracking of cash receipts and payments

1.2 The Challenge: Implementing the Direct Method

While the direct method provides superior information, most companies avoid it due to implementation challenges. The main obstacle is that traditional accounting systems record transactions by account, not by cash flow categories. To prepare a direct method cash flow statement, you need to:

  1. Identify cash transactions among all recorded transactions
  2. Classify each cash flow into the appropriate category
  3. Match cash receipts and payments to understand the complete cash flow picture

This is where offsetting account determination becomes invaluable.

1.3 How Offsetting Account Determination Enables Direct Method Cash Flow

Offsetting account determination is a sophisticated process that automatically pairs each debit posting with exactly one credit posting in your accounting documents. Here's how it works and why it's crucial for direct method cash flow statements:

The Pairing Process

When you post a transaction, the system automatically:

  1. Identifies offsetting accounts for each G/L account line item
  2. Creates paired relationships between debits and credits
  3. Stores the pairing information for reporting purposes

Practical Example: Supplier Invoice

Consider a supplier invoice posting:

Before Offsetting Account Determination:

Account                          Debit    Credit
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,180

After Offsetting Account Determination:

Pairing 1:
Goods Receipt/Invoice Receipt    $1,000    -
Accounts Payable                 -         $1,000

Pairing 2:
Deferred Tax                     $180      -
Accounts Payable                 -         $180

This pairing process provides several advantages:

  1. Automatic Cash Flow Classification: Each cash payment can be automatically classified based on its offsetting account
  2. Detailed Transaction Tracking: You can trace exactly what each cash flow represents
  3. Accurate Reporting: Eliminates guesswork in categorizing cash flows
  4. Audit Trail: Provides clear documentation of cash flow sources and uses

 

2. Getting Started with SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements

The video tutorials that follow are designed to provide hands-on guidance for both technical implementers and business users. Each tutorial builds upon the previous one, creating a complete learning path that ensures successful implementation and adoption of the solution. All videos can also be accessed through this playlist: Step-by-Step Implementing SAP DRC Cash Flow Statements 

What You'll Gain from This Implementation Guide

By following this step-by-step approach, you'll be able to:

  • Understand the complete cash flow statement landscape and choose the right method for your organization
  • Configure both direct and indirect methods with proper SAP DRC framework setup
  • Implement advanced features like offsetting account determination for superior cash flow visibility
  • Handle real-world scenarios with practical examples and troubleshooting guidance

2.1 Video Tutorial 1: Understanding Cash Flow Statements

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_pnx4sufg

This introductory video provides a comprehensive overview of cash flow statements and their importance in financial reporting.

Key Topics Covered:

  • Background and Context: Why cash flow statements matter for businesses
  • Regulatory Requirements: How different countries mandate cash flow reporting
  • Two Methods Explained: Direct vs. Indirect method differences
  • SAP Solution Overview: How SAP S/4HANA supports both methods

 

2.2 Video Tutorial 2: How to Use SAP DRC Cash Flow Statement

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_mycrc7yw

This comprehensive tutorial demonstrates the practical steps for using the SAP DRC cash flow statement solution in your daily operations, including advanced analytical features.

Key Features Demonstrated:

  • Report Navigation: Finding cash flow statements in the Run Statutory Report app
  • Filter Configuration: Setting up proper filters for reporting status, entity, and period
  • Report Generation: Step-by-step process for creating new cash flow statements
  • File Management: Understanding generated PDF and ALV table views

 

2.3 Video Tutorial 3: Configure Statutory Reporting Framework

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_y50w1v3l

This configuration tutorial covers the essential setup steps for the statutory reporting framework that forms the foundation of the SAP DRC cash flow solution.

Configuration Overview:

  • Report Entity Definition: Setting up country-specific entities
  • Report Categories: Configuring direct and indirect method categories
  • Periodicity Parameters: Defining reporting frequency and due dates
  • Organization Unit Assignment: Mapping company codes to reporting entities

 

2.4 Video Tutorial 4: Setting Up Direct Method Cash Flow Statements

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_92z3ujqp

This detailed configuration tutorial covers all aspects of setting up the direct method cash flow statement, including the essential offsetting account determination functionality.

Configuration Overview:

1. Direct Method Configuration

  • Cash Flow Statement Version: Defining reporting structure and hierarchy
  • Account Assignment: Configuring cash, offsetting, and invoice accounts
  • Item Types and Modes: Understanding calculation attributes
  • Limiting Parameters: Setting up transaction type filters

Note:  Selectable limiting parameters are coming from ACDOCA table. Please check the meaning of parameters there and check available field values in relevant check/configuration tables. For example, the Transaction Type here refer to ACDOCA-RMVCT, which should be configured by SSCUI: Maintain Transaction Types for Consolidation (ID: 102366). To ensure the field is available on UI when creating accounting document, please also check the field status by SSCUI: Define Field Status Variants (ID: 102393)

2. Offsetting Account Determination

  • Version Definition: Creating determination rules for document splitting
  • Preferred Pairs: Setting up priority account combinations
  • Forbidden Pairs: Preventing inappropriate account pairings
  • Activation Process: Enabling the solution for specific document types

 

2.5 Video Tutorial 5: Configure Indirect Method Cash Flow Statement

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_3q5sgz07

This configuration tutorial covers the setup for indirect method cash flow statements, which is simpler than direct method but still requires proper configuration.

Configuration Overview:

  • Separate Version ID: Creating dedicated indirect method versions
  • Balance-Based Items: Configuring GL balance calculations

 

2.6 Video Tutorial 6: Real-World Examples - Sample Business Cases

Video Link: https://sapvideo.cfapps.eu10-004.hana.ondemand.com/?entry_id=1_x7zjnu6g

This practical tutorial demonstrates three common business scenarios and how the SAP DRC solution handles each case automatically.

Sample Case 1: Payment for Purchase

  • Outgoing payment to supplier
  • AP invoice with expense classification
  • Clearing relationship between payment and invoice

Sample Case 2: Bank in Transit

  • Bank statement posting with bank in transit
  • Customer payment clearing through transit account
  • Customer invoice with revenue recognition

Sample Case 3: Goods Receipt Account (GR/IR)

  • Purchase order with goods receipt and invoice receipt
  • GR/IR account usage in purchasing process
  • Complex clearing relationships

 

3. Conclusion

SAP DRC cash flow statements provide powerful financial reporting capabilities for organizations worldwide. The direct method offers superior cash flow visibility through offsetting account determination, while the indirect method provides a simpler implementation path.

Next Steps:

  1. Check SAP Help Portal for your country's specific DRC Reports.
  2. Download the implementation guide slides used in the videos.
  3. Join the SAP DRC Community for ongoing support and updates.

entry.title: Managing Legacy Files for India GSTR reports in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance
entry.content:
Introduction 

When implementing SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for GST reporting in India, it may be necessary to store legacy GST-filed documents and responses (for example, GSTR1 filling json, GSTR3B etc.) from the GSTN for future reference and audit purposes. This blog presents a practical approach to manually storing and managing previously reported files within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance by using Attachment section in the Generated Run. 

Disclaimer: This document does not replace a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Part 1: Technical Prerequisites 

Step 1: Create a Custom Report Definition 

Begin by setting up a custom report definition to manage historical files. This involves: 

  • Custom Report Definition: Tailor a report specifically for historical data. 
  • Corresponding Report Category: Categorize the report appropriately. 
  • Custom Entity: Create if necessary. 

 for example, ZIN_GSTR1 or YIN_GSTR1 etc. 

Note: Either you can use the same Z or Y report created above, across multiple GST reports or you can create a new report based on the functionality. 

Refer to SAP Documentation for detailed instructions on defining statutory reports SAP Documentation – Define Statutory Reports for creating above-mentioned objects. 

Step 2: Define a Schema 

During setting up the document section in report definition, you must specify a schema or ABAP structure to define the document layout. Use the following sample JSON structure to facilitate file uploads: 

{ 

    "title": "India GSTR Reporting", 

    "type": "object", 

    "properties": { 

        "CompanyCode": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[0-9]{4}$", 

            "description": "4-digit company code" 

        }, 

        "Country": { 

            "type": "string", 

            "pattern": "^[a-zA-Z]{2}$", 

            "description": "2-letter ISO country code (e.g., IN or In)" 

        } 

    } 

}

Save this schema as a .json file and upload it during report definition configuration. 

Note: The same schema can be used across multiple GST reports. 

Step 3: Configure Document Mapping 

Assign static (literal) values for required fields to simplify the upload process, such as: 

  • Company Code: 1810 
  • Country: IN 

 

 

  

Part 2: Storing Attachments in Document and Reporting Compliance 

Step 1: Generate a Report Run 

Create a new reporting run for the relevant period. This serves as a placeholder for document storage. 

Note: This run is intended only to facilitate document storage. Make sure to consider any storage limitations related to the attachment service. 

Disclaimer: It is not a substitute for a legally required or system-generated statutory file. 

Step 2: Navigate to the Run 

Locate your custom report and the run you created in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance application. 

 

 

Step 3: Access the Attachments Tab 

Switch to the Attachments tab within the selected run. 

 

 

Step 4: Upload Your Historical File 

Click on Upload and select the desired historical file from your computer

 

 

Step 5: Save the Attachment 

Click Save Attachment to securely store the file in the system for future reference. 

 

 

Conclusion 

By utilizing custom report definitions and the Attachments feature, organizations can centralize access to both new and historical statutory filing records within SAP Document and Reporting Compliance. This method ensures a consistent and auditable compliance process, regardless of your adoption timeline or transitions between reporting solutions.

entry.title: Creating Custom 'Document Definition' as part of 'Document and Reporting Compliance' process of SAP
entry.content:
Hello all, 

With this Blog post I would like to share my latest experience working with 'Document and Reporting Compliance' component of SAP, which is used for generating Statutory Reports and SAP has already shipped Country-specific compliant Report Templates (pdf template is what we are going to cover as part of this post) as part of this feature/framework/component, still there might be some scenarios where we would need some Custom Changes to be incorporated into the SAP shipped Document Definitions and a similar case am going to elaborate here in which we made some changes in the pdf format Document of the Italian Fixed Asset Register(IT_FXDAST_REG) Report Definition by copying the same to a Custom Version and thereby applying the needed changes as per customer requirement.

Apart from pdf below are the other Document Formats supported (here mainly we would be discussing pdf Document type)

Helpful links:

  • This link talks about the whole 'Statutory Reporting component (this link could be skipped and the subsequent document could be referred if one is already acquainted with the 'Statutory Reporting process of SAP'). Statutory Reporting
  • Our main focus as part of this post would be 'Defining Custom Statutory Reports by referring the SAP Shipped Report Definition (it's recommended to go through the document before proceeding ahead in order to understand the various sub-components involved like Parameter Definition, Query Definition , Document Definition , Schema, PDF Form Template etc. and how all these components are inter-linked). Define Statutory Reports  

Scope of this post:

  • 'Define Statutory Reports' section as part of Setting up the Statutory Reporting process would be covered which is done using a Fiori app with same name. Custom Development is required at this part of the process only which would be the main topic to be covered as part of this post.
  • SPRO Configurations required for Setting up the 'Run Compliance Reports' won't be covered as part of this post. Above mentioned helpful links and the already shipped Configurations should help in understanding and setting up the same.

Recommended having prior knowledge of:

  • XML Interface based AdobeForm building.
  • Little Knowledge of XML based .xsd Schema files.

Requirement: Requirement was to make some changes (adding some fields at Header and Item level) in the pdf format Document of the Italian Fixed Asset Register(IT_FXDAST_REG) Report Definition by copying the same to a Custom Version and thereby applying the needed changes as per the customer requirement.

Details of the steps involved:

Step 1 : Copy standard Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' to a Custom one say 'YY_TEST_IT_FXDAST_REG'

This step will copy all the below mentioned 7 components of the Report Definition, out of these 3rd and 4th i.e. Query Definition and Document Definition respectively are the most important one for carrying out the Custom Changes.

i.) Properties

ii.) Parameter Definition

iii.) Query Definition

iv.) Document Definition

v.) Correspondence Definition

vi) Event Handler

vii.) Reported Items Log

Understanding the Parameter Definition, Query Definition and Document Definition components above briefly. Recommended to go through the document Creating a Report Definition

a.) Parameter Definition : This step defines the Input Parameters and its properties for a Report e.g. what and all should be the Input Parameters like Company Code , Asset Class etc. and the properties of these Input Parameters like Optional, Hidden, Read-Only etc. In-short its the same as defining the Selection Screen in ABAP ALV Report. Values for these Parameters are set during the Setting up of 'Run Compliance Reports' procedure.

Note: Activate this before proceeding to the next step else you won't be able to use these properly in the subsequent steps. In most cases you won't need to make any changes here. 

b.) Query Definition : As part of a Report  Document/Output there would be various Entities (like Header fields , Item columns , Footer fields etc.) which we would need to get filled or populated with respective data, using Query Definition option you can define the various Re-usable queries which can be used to map with the various entities of the final Report Document/Output.

Below is the overview of various Queries available as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' , 

Note: Here, we have added one Custom Query and also we have Changed the Source of an Existing Query. 

Note: A Query can be defined with any of the below listed Data Source types:

c.) Document Definition : It's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process. While creating the document definition, you can also assign an existing schema, or create a new schema for the document. It is at this step where we map various entities/nodes of the final legal Report document with the Re-useable queries we defined in the previous step. Documents of Type XML, TXT, ALV, JSON, PDF and XBRL can be defined as part of this step. As part of this post we would be focusing mainly on the pdf Document Type.

Step 2 : Working with the Query Definition.

Here, we will define a new Query with Data Source Type as 'Database Table' and also we will customize an existing Query-Class based Query by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

a.) Creating a Custom Query with Data Source of type 'Database Tables'

Select Data Source Type as 'Database Tables/Views' from the drop down and provide the Table name in the Data Source Name field.

Scroll down and in the Filters section set the filters, Note: Here, Set the Filter as per the mapping cardinality(this is part of the next step that is Document Definition mapping). Suppose, if the cardinality is 1:1 that means only one record is expected to be fetched and returned by this query hence, the Filter parameter should also be passed accordingly, such that it returns only one record.

Here, for the field ANLKL (Asset Class) of Table ANKA we are setting the Filter criteria by passing value from the output of another Existing Query called FILE_SPLIT.

So this is just like below SELECT SINGLE query,

SELECT SINGLE * FROM anka WHERE anlkl EQ file_split-assetclass

b.) Customizing existing Query-Class based Query 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'  by attaching a Z Custom Class to it as Data Source.

Here, we copied the Standard Query Class CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA to Z_TEST_CL_FIAAIT_REG_DATA and will make Changes in the Method 'GET_PDF_TOTAL_ASST_CLSS' which is indeed responsible for filling data into this Query that is 'TOTAL_ASST_CLSS'. What we did is added a Custom field in the Output Structure and filled some dummy value as shown below,

Set the Parameters same as it was before for this Query, note Whenever you change the Data Source Type of a Query its Paramters need to be set again.

Finally Select all the Queries and Activate them, Note: Until and unless all the Queries are activated you wont be able to use them in subsequent steps.

Step 3 : Working with the Document Definition.

Note: Refer the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' in parallel for understanding how various parameters need to be set while configuring this part.

Finally it's in this step where we would define or say structure the layout of the legal Report documents that should get generated during the Statutory Reporting process and map all the output elements with the Queries we created above in the previous step.

a.) Click on Add option and select 'Add with Schema/Query' from the drop-down and provide the Document ID ( e.g. here it is 'YYIT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' ) and set Document Type as 'PDF'

Now, here we need to maintain the Schema, which is the most important part of Report Definition. Schema is the metadata or say skeleton of the Data Service which would be use in this case for providing the Interface/Context/Data to the AdobeForm which we would indeed used for Binding the output elements in AdobeForm Layout.

Note: Here we need to define a new Schema and hence Schema ID reason being we are going to add some Custom Fields which is not part of the Standard SAP Shipped Schema and Document.

If you check the Standard pdf Report Document 'IT_FXDAST_REGISTER_PDF' shipped as part of Report Definition 'IT_FXDAST_REG' the Schema ID attached there is 'IT_FXDAST_REG_7'. entry.title: Inflation Accounting in Türkiye – Index-Based Asset Revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, SAP now supports a significant legal requirement in Türkiye: index-based asset revaluation. (Inflation Accounting). 
Note: For the "What's New" Article, please click here.

This regulation, mandated by Turkish tax and commercial law, requires companies to revalue their fixed assets based on monthly inflation indices published by the Turkish Statistical Institute (TÜİK).
This blog provides an overview of the legal requirement and explains how to meet it by demonstrating the implementation steps for a sample scenario.

About Index-Based Asset Revaluation in Türkiye

Index-based asset revaluation is a legal requirement in Türkiye introduced under the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the Official Gazette (issue 32415, 30.12.2023).
This regulation requires companies to adjust their financial statements based on producer price indices published by TÜİK (Turkish Statistical Institute).

The calculation of the adjustment coefficient is defined in Article 17 of the Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği (Sıra No: 555), published in the official Gazette (Resmi Gazete, issue 32415, 30.12.2023):

  • Five decimal places must be considered in the calculation.
  • The fifth digit must be rounded based on the sixth digit.

The official index values can be found here.

Note: Each customer is responsible for ensuring that the maintained index values and resulting calculations (including rounding) comply with the legal requirements!

 

Implementation Guide

This section explains the implementation steps of index-based revaluation in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for a sample scenario involving a simple asset. It lists the steps required to complete the set-up, posting, valuation checks, a partial retirement, and (optionally) a reversal.

Note:

  • The revaluation is not carried out in a separate depreciation area, but within the valuation view where the index is assigned (e.g. 1 = Book Depreciation, 15 = Local Tax).
  • Customers should not use the scope item for additional depreciation areas for this purpose, as adding extra areas does not support the revaluation process and will not provide the intended outcome.

Scenario Details

  • Asset APC: 12,000 TRY
  • Useful life: 10 years (120 periods)
  • Valuation view: The view where the index is assigned (e.g., 1 = Book Depreciation or 15 = Local Tax)
  • Revaluation index: Monthly index (assigned before acquisition)
  • Scenario extension: Partial retirement of 70% on 01 Mach 2025; optional reversal of postings

Prerequisites

Maintain G/L account determination for revaluation in the Assign G/L Accounts (ID: 102622) configuration activity.

Step-by-Step Procedure

  1. Create revaluation index
    1. Open the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app and create a new index with the following details:
      1. Revaluation Index ID: Freely selectable (e.g. INF_TR)
      2. Index Type: Replacement Value, Monthly
      3. Unit of Measure: Index Points
    2. Maintain the monthly index values published by TÜİK: TÜIK Inflation and Price Statistics

    3. Activate the revaluation index by clicking on "Activate" to make it available for valuation views.

       

  2. Maintain asset master data
    1. Open the Manage Fixed Assets app.
    2. Create a new asset and maintain all mandatory values (cost centre, profit centre, segment) and other values relevant to your business.
    3. Under Valuation → General Parameters, assign the revaluation index created in step 1.


    4. Adjust the useful life (in years) if necessary, for example, 10 years.
    5. Apply changes and save.

  3. Post acquisition of the asset
    1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Acquisition → Acquisition (Net).

       

    2. In the new window, specify values for the following mandatory fields:
      1.          Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date
      2.          Amount Posted in Transaction Currency (12,000 TRY in our example)
      3.          Year of Acquisition (Prior Year in our example)
    3. Choose Simulate to check the postings and then choose Post.

  4. View depreciation amounts
    1. In the Managed Fixed Assets app, go to Valuation to review the effects of revaluation.
    2. Under Value Display → Depreciation, you will see both the regular depreciation and the additional revaluation amounts

      Fiscal Year 2024:

      Fiscal Year 2025:

Scenario Extension: The asset was acquired in July 2024 for 12,000 TRY. In March 2025, 70% of the asset needs to be retired.

  1. In the Manage Fixed Assets app, choose Post → Post Retirement → Retirement without Revenue.


  2. Adjust the mandatory fields:
    • Journal Entry Date, Posting Date, Asset Value Date to 01.03.2025
    • Retirement Type: Partial Retirement by Percentage Rate
    • Retirement Percentage: 70 %
    • Year of Acquisition: Prior Year

    • Choose Post.
    • The results can be viewed under Valuation.

Option: Reverse a posting, if required:

  1. Open the Reverse Journal Entries – In Asset Accounting app.
  2. Select the journal entry.
  3. Specify the mandatory values.
  4. Choose Reverse.

     

Annual Index Maintenance for 2025

According to the 582nd Sequence of the Tax Procedure Law (Vergi Usul Kanunu Genel Tebliği, Sıra No: 582, published 15.02.2025), inflation accounting will not be applied for the first, second, and third provisional tax periods of 2025 (except for certain exempt taxpayers such as jewelers).
This change means that for 2025, the adjustment will only be performed once at the end of the year (31.12.2025).

Source: TÜRMOB – 2025 Yılı Geçici Vergi Dönemlerinde Enflasyon Düzeltmesi Yapılmayacak 

Following the legal change in February 2025, inflation accounting in Türkiye is now applied annually, not monthly or quarterly.
For 2025, the calculation will be based on the difference between the index value as of 31.12.2024 and the index value as of 31.12.2025.

Since no interim calculation is legally required, companies may enter “0” for the index values from January to November and enter the actual year-end value only in December.

This ensures that the adjustment is calculated exclusively at year-end, as required by law.

Disclaimer: This approach is based on current interpretations. Customers are responsible for verifying its legal validity for their specific case and ensuring compliance from both a regulatory and audit perspective.

 

Automated Index Maintenance via API

Instead of manually maintaining index values in the Maintain Asset Revaluation Index app, you can automate the process using the API API_ASSETREVALUATIONINDEX.
The API allows you to manage both the index header (ID, type, country/currency, unit of measure) and the monthly values (Valid From, Valid To, Index Value) programmatically.

 

Use Case
For example, companies can implement an SAP BTP integration or a partner app that retrieves official TÜİK data each month, validates it, and automatically writes it to their SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system. This removes the need for manual entry and ensures consistent, repeatable index maintenance.

Further Information: API Documentation on SAP Help Portal 

Automated Calculation via BadI

The BAdI FAA_DC_UPA_CUSTOMER with the method SET_PERCENT_VALUE can be used to define formulas for calculating percentage changes automatically.

Example:

Adjustment Coefficient = ((Index value current month / Index value previous month) – 1) * 100

Important: While both SET_PERCENT_VALUE and SET_BASE_VALUE methods are available as of 508, there is a known limitation when using them in scenarios with Periodic Revaluation and Depreciation Split.
In such scenarios, customers should not use the BAdI until this gap is resolved.

Further Information: Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects 

Support

If you’d like to use the new index type in Türkiye, please create a support incident using the component FI-LOC-FI-TR. To use the feature for other supported countries, use the relevant components.

For more information, refer to the documentation on SAP Help Portal: Maintain Asset Revaluation Index  and Index Type "Replacement Value, Monthly".

Conclusion

The new functionality in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 allows Turkish companies to comply with the legal requirements for inflation accounting and index-based revaluation of assets.

entry.title: SII tip for Spain #5: SII Adjustments for Canary Islands October 2025
entry.content:
The Canary Islands is an Spanish region which, due to certain particularities and specifications, such as its geographical location, the scarcity of natural resources or distance to the EU continent ( it is an outermost region of the European Union), has a different economic and fiscal regime from the rest of the Spanish territory.

This mainly means that while being part of the EU customs territory and having the same customs legislation, indirect taxation is different and there is a specific tax for this part of the EU customs territory. In the Canary Islands, for example, Value Added Tax (VAT) or certain Excise Taxes do not apply. Instead, the transport operations to the Canary Islands are subject to own tax such as the General Indirect Canary Tax (IGIC), the Tax on Petroleum Derived Fuels or the Tax on Imports and Deliveries of Goods in the Canary Islands (AIEM).

The Canary Islands Tax Agency published the Order of July 10, 2025 modifying Order of 11 October 2018, regulating the technical and legal specifications of the IGIC registry books  containing a set of changes in the Canary Islands SII format.  In the Annex of the given Order, the technical specifications are detailed.

The summary of the changes contained in the new Law are the following.

New Regimes

Regime (ClaveRegimenEspecialOTrascendencia) "08", currently for Transactions subject to VAT/IPSI is split into two:

  • In case of incoming invoices: 
    • Regime "08" (Transactions subject to VAT)
    • New Regime "18" (Transactions subject toIPSI)
  • In case of outgoing invoices:
    • Regime "08" (Transactions subject to VAT)
    • New Regime "20" (Transactions subject to IPSI)

Additionally,  new combinations of regime 18  (incoming invoices) are required:

 

New combinations of regime 20 (outgoing invoices) are also provided:

 

 

 

The new Regimes will be available in the SII customzing for incoming and for outgoing invoices. The SII will support the same combinations for of regimes 18 and 20 as they were supported for the original 08.

AIEM tax

New XML structure <OperacionSujetaAIEM> . In case the transaction is subject to AIEM (supplies made by companies, on a regular or occasional basis for commercial reasons, of manufactured personal movable property as included in annex IV of Law 24/2001,  and also the imports of the goods listed in the Annex IV):  

  • The AIEM amount shall be separated from the IGIC amount (<CuotaSoportada>)
  • The summary of the AIEM amount shall be reported in the new tag <CuotaAIEM> in the new XML structure.
  • The deductible amount in case of incoming invoices (<CuotaDeducible>) shall not include the AIEM amount
  • The total amount of the invoice (<ImporteTotal>) shall include also the AIEM amount in case this optional field is reported

 

Customers subject to AIEM are required to extend the Spanish tax procedure with their own AIEM transactions keys (for example, ZAI for AIEM input, o ZAO for AIEM output).

 

A new customizing activity in  SII will allow the use to define the new transaction keys for AIEM tax (SSCUI 107186, “Assign Settings for Accounting Key Tax Type”).

The Canary Islands SII process will check this customizing activity and populate the tags <CuotaAIEM> , <CuotaDeducible> and <ImporteTotal> (if required) .

 

Special taxes managed by the Canary Islands Tax Agency

New XML structure <OperacionSujetaIIEEgestCAC>. In case the transaction is subject to the special taxes managed  by the Canary Islands Tax Agency (such as Tobacco, Petroleum-based fuels and Wastes deposited in landfills for incineration and co-incineration), the new tags under this new structure must be populated:

  • <ClaveImpuestoEspecial>
  • <Exenta>
  • <RegimenSuspensivo>
  • <CuotaIIEECAC>

Customers with transactions subject to the these special taxes can use method SET_OUTPUT_DATA of BAdI EDOC_ADAPTOR to fill these fields

 

Timeline

We are currently working in finalizing the solution by October 2025. Please check the announcement "SII for Canary Islands 2025" in the Regulatory Change Manager for further details.

In case of additional questions, you can visit the SII help documentation in the following links:

  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in S/4HANA Private Cloud
  • Electronic Tax Register Books with SII in ERP

Other SII tips:

  • SII tip for Spain #4: Errors 1116, 1117 and 2011: Issues with the Identification service

entry.title: SAP DRC e-invoicing and e-way bill - INDIA Localization
entry.content:
Document and reporting compliance enables the transformation of documents created in various SAP applications into predefined exchange formats and transfer them electronically to external systems, such as to the systems of legal or tax authorities. In India e-Documents can be created for the following document types:

  • Customer invoices created from billing or accounting documents
  • Invoice verification
  • Credit memos
  • Debit memos
  • Real estate invoices

The end-to-end process requires to use one of the supported GST Suvidha Providers (GSPs). For more information about third-party service providers check SAP Note 3556797

High Level View

In India mainly TWO tasks are associated with e-document

  • e-Way Bill - You can send invoices or delivery challans electronically to the government agency to obtain a valid e-waybill number which is needed before starting goods movement. As per the Goods and Service Tax (GST) law in India, a registered taxpayer, prior to movement of goods via a conveyance, needs to inform each transaction’s details to the tax department and generate an e-way bill for such movements. There are certain exemptions and exclusions from the requirement for e-way bills. Electronic Way Bill is a valid document accompanying the transport vehicle.
  • e-invoice - You can register invoices electronically with the Invoice Registration Portal to obtain the Invoice Registration Number (IRN) and it becomes a legally valid e-invoice.

Direct integration to e-Invoicing (IRN) system via GSP. This is a licensed solution developed by SAP which will provide direct integration between the SAP ECC or SAP S/4HANA On-Prem systems or S/4HANA Cloud and the Government e-Invoicing platform via certified GSPs using the SAP Cloud Integration Platform. This will enable taxpayers to upload the payload from the backend SAP system to the e-Invoicing (IRN) portal, generate the Invoice Reference Number and link the Invoice Reference Number (IRN) with the billing document in the backend system.

FOUR Parameters to generate IRN

  • Supplier GSTIN
  • Supplier’s invoice number
  • Document Type (INV/CRN/DBN)
  • Financial year (YYYY-YY)

EIGHT Parameters to generate a QR Code

  • GSTIN of Supplier
  • GSTIN of Recipient
  • Invoice number as given by Supplier
  • Date of generation of invoice
  • Invoice value (taxable value and gross tax)
  • Number of line items
  • HSN Code of main item (the line item having highest taxable value)
  • Unique Invoice Reference Number (hash)

Key Statutory Reports (can be executed in Fiori)

  • GSTR1 Report - In India, the GSTR1 Report is a monthly return that should be filed by every registered businesses. It contains details of all outward supplies.
  • GSTR3B Report - GSTR3B is a monthly return to be filed by a registered GST taxpayer in India. It's a simplified return that consolidates the details of outward & inward supplies.
  • ITC04 Report - The form ITC04 is a declaration submitted by registered principals to report details of inputs and capital goods sent to or received from job workers during a specified tax period, in compliance with GST regulations. It stands for Input Tax Credit 04.
  • GSTR 6 Report - The GSTR 6 report provides you details of all the documents issued for distribution of input tax credit and the manner of distribution of credit and tax invoice on which credit is received.
  • Withholding Tax Reporting - Process invoice and payment documents posted within the reporting period and generate withholding tax report for submission to the tax authorities.

Pre Requisites

  • Licenses are obtained.
  • Business place setup to have GST Number
  • BP Master data equipped with IN3 (GST number) and IN2 (TIN No) Tax category.
  • For e-Invoicing as a prerequisite ODN number range should have been defined by Finance team
  • Material Master to have proper HSN/SAC codes.
  • Condition based Tax Procedure for India is already in place.
  • Tax Codes are available in system for country India.

Install and implement all the e-invoice relevant notes:

  • 3516531 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Prerequisite for SAP Note 3512964
  • 3512964 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Enabling the E-Invoice Solution for SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition
  • 3516185 - Electronic Document Processing for India - E-Invoice Solution Package Creation
  • 3479282 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Prerequisite for SAP Note 3516183
  • 3516183 - Electronic Document Processing for India - AIF Enabling the E-Invoice Solution
  • 3575681 - eDocument India: DCS Integration Issue
  • 3565298 - Electronic Document Processing for India: Automatic Status Update for Electronic Documents
  • 3586310 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Waybill - Error message appears when you cancel the eDocument
  • 3586081 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Waybill - Log not found while submitting the eDocument
  • 3584664 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice- Log not found while cancelling e-invoice
  • 3599008 - Electronic Document Processing for India - Enabling the Error Analysis for Manage Electronic Documents App ( E-Invoice Solution)
  • 3580437 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice - Correction for eDocument India eInvoice Enhancements BAdI
  • 3637865 - Electronic Document Processing for India: E-Invoice - Viewing Error Reasons in Application Log for E-Invoice

Configuration details – E Way bills

Configuration details – E invoice

Cancellation Process

e-Way cancellation:

  • If the goods were never transported or are not transported as per the details furnished in the Electronic Document (eDocument).
  • In such a scenario, you cancel the eWay bill. During cancelation you enter the valid reason for cancellation. For example, the goods are not being moved, incorrect entry in the eWay bill entered. Note that for this scenario, you do not cancel the eDocument.
  • To cancel only the eWay bill and not the eDocument, do not set the Cancel eDocument checkbox.
  • If you do not set the Cancel eDocument checkbox, the system cancels the eWay bill number generated by tax authority. In such a scenario, the eDocument is still available. If required later, you can generate the eWay bill for the eDocument
  • If you set the Cancel eDocument checkbox, the system cancels the eDocument. In such a scenario you will have to additionally cancel the source document.

e-Invoice cancellation:

According to govt, IRN cancellation can only happen within 24 hours of its generation. Any cancellation after 24hrs could not be possible on IRN, however one can manually cancel the same on the GST portal before filing the returns.

If the source document needs to be canceled in SAP post 24 hours of IRN generation:

  1. Perform the ‘Cancel eDocument’ action under ‘More’ in EDOC_COCKPIT and it should fail with the error “Error Code 2270: The allowed cancellation time limit is crossed, you cannot cancel the IRN.”
  2. Use the ‘Allow Cancellation’ action under ‘More’ in EDOC_COCKPIT to enable the cancellation of the source document. The status will be changed to ‘ALLOW_CANCEL’ to allow source document cancellation.

Note: This does not have any impact on IRP portal data and only allows to cancel source document in the SAP system. After canceling the source document, ensure to cancel the outward liability while filing GSTR1 returns.

Manual correction option:

In case the automated solution is being used for an e-Invoice generation but the e-Invoice got generated offline, later eDocument status can be updated using contingency mode. The contingency report J1IGIRN can be used to upload the IRN response file back to EDOC_COCKPIT.

Download the respective response JSON file from the IRP portal and upload it in the J1IGIRN transaction. The e-Document status will get updated and associates the IRN details in e-Document tables.

entry.title: Oman localization in SAP S/4HANA Cloud: what matters for Implementation and beyond
entry.content:
If you are rolling out SAP S/4HANA Cloud in Oman, localization is not an afterthought—it’s your go‑live runway. SAP provides a dedicated Oman node on the Help Portal that consolidates scope, configuration, and reporting activities aligned to local law and practice.

What’s in scope

  • VAT: Generate the quarterly VAT Return using Run Statutory Reports, with predefined tax boxes for sales and purchase scenarios as well as reverse‑charge coverage for imported goods/services. You can analyze, adjust, export, and manage correction phases directly from the reporting task. 
     
  • Withholding tax (Form 18): Declaration focused on payments to foreign suppliers, supported by a guided sequence—manage items, review, clear, prepare—plus parameters such as principal‑officer details. 
     
  • Cash flow statement: Produce the OM_CASHFLOW (indirect method) via the same Document and reporting compliance framework, using the OMCF financial statement version. 
     
  • Official document numbering (ODN): Enforce unique fiscal‑year serials for invoices and related notes through country key OM, document classes (OIN/OCN/ODN), number groups, and ranges. 
     
  • Postdated checks (PDC): End‑to‑end handling—receive, present to bank/vendor, clear/bounce, reverse, and track history—using the Bills of Exchange apps. 
     
  • Sales billing forms: Predelivered Oman templates for customer invoices and credit memos streamline compliant output.

Set‑up essentials
Start with master data: maintain VAT registration numbers for company codes and business partners (format: OM + 10 digits). If applicable, define HSN/SAC codes and apply material tax indicators/classifications. Establish reporting entities and categories you’ll run most often—OM_RPG_ENT, OM_VAT_RET, OM_WHT_FORM18_DCL, OM_CASHFLOW—and complete activity‑specific parameters (for example, principal‑officer data for Form 18). 

Operate & report
Your daily driver is Run Statutory Reports: prepare the run, analyze and adjust, preview/ export, then (manually) submit to authorities and update the submission status. When you need corrections, open a new phase for a full or delta rerun as appropriate. 

Looking Ahead: E-Invoicing in Oman
Oman is moving toward mandatory e-invoicing, with a expected phased rollout starting in Q3 2026 most probably under the PEPPOL 5-corner model. This shift would require businesses to adopt structured invoice formats and integrate with accredited service providers.

Please read the blog for more details.

SAP Plans to deliver an e-invoicing solution for Oman as part of its continuous localization roadmap. Customers can expect capabilities aligned with OTA requirements, leveraging SAP Document and Reporting Compliance for seamless integration and compliance.

For the latest details and planned delivery timelines, Subscribe and stay tuned to SAP Regulatory Change Manager. This is your single source for official updates on regulatory changes and SAP’s enablement plans.

Takeaway
With pre‑delivered content across VAT, withholding tax, cash flow, ODN, PDC, and billing forms, Oman localization helps you cut risk and standardize close and reporting. Bookmark the Oman Help Portal entry and use it as your implementation playbook. 

Ready to make your Oman rollout smooth and compliant? Dive into the SAP Help Portal for detailed guidance and keep an eye on the Regulatory Change Manager for e-invoicing updates. Got questions? Share them in the comments—we’d love to hear your perspective.

entry.title: Localization in SAP S/4HANA: Strategic Enabler or Deployment Bottleneck?
entry.content:
Localization is a foundational element in global SAP rollouts, and recognizing its importance early can significantly enhance deployment outcomes. It’s not just about translating interfaces or formatting currencies—it’s about aligning enterprise systems with country-specific legal, fiscal, and operational requirements. When overlooked, localization can become a deployment bottleneck, delaying go-lives and increasing compliance risks.

Key Localization Areas and Their Impacts

  1. Statutory Compliance

Governments mandate specific reporting formats such as SAF-T, e-invoicing, and VAT declarations. SAP S/4HANA must be configured to generate these outputs accurately and on time. Non-compliance can result in penalties or operational disruptions.

  1. Taxation and Financial Reporting

Localization affects tax codes, withholding tax logic, and financial statement structures. Country-specific requirements—like India’s GST or Saudi Arabia’s einvoicing—require localized configurations across Finance, Procurement, and Sales modules.

  1. Payment and Banking Formats

Local banks often require country specific payment formats (e.g., ISO 20022, MT940, CNAB). These influence integration design and middleware configurations and can delay testing if not scoped early.

  1. Language Localization

Beyond translation, cultural nuances such as date formats, decimal separators, and naming conventions impact usability and data integrity—especially in HR and Payroll modules.

  1. Legal Document Templates

Invoices, delivery notes, and contracts must meet local legal standards. SAP Smart Forms or Adobe Forms need to be customized per country, impacting development timelines and testing cycles.

  1. Master Data Localization

Country-specific fields (e.g., tax registration numbers, local address formats) must be embedded in master data models. This affects data migration, validation, and governance.

SAP’s Localization Toolkit

SAP supports localization through country versions, localization packs, and extensibility frameworks. The SAP Globalization Services offer Solutions, tools and content to meet local requirements. However, their effectiveness depends on early planning and sometimes cross-functional collaboration spanning across various modules.

Conclusion

Localization is not a technical detail—it’s a strategic enabler. Treating it as pivotal element in your implementations ensures smoother deployments, better compliance, and higher user adoption across geographies. Successful SAP programs embed localization into design workshops, testing cycles, and governance models from day one.

It is a strategic Enabler

When localization enables companies to:

  • Comply with local laws and regulations (e.g., tax, e-invoicing, statutory reporting).
  • Operate efficiently across geographies, adapting business processes to local norms.
  • Improve user adoption by aligning interfaces and workflows with local expectations.
  • Avoid legal and financial risks through accurate configuration of country-specific requirements.

It is a deployment Bottleneck

When localization is:

  • Underestimated or delayed, it can cause project overruns.
  • Treated as a post-go-live activity, it leads to rework and compliance gaps.

entry.title: Peppol Participant Registration for Belgian Companies
entry.content:
As of January 1, 2026, Belgian companies are required to exchange electronic invoices that are compliant with the European semantic and syntactic standard (EN 16931) with their business partners. The Peppol network is the secure network for this exchange, and companies need to register a participant for their company in this network. If you’re facing the task of registering your company in the Peppol network, this blog provides you with simple tips and guidance.

For more information about the Belgian legal change, see the Regulatory Change Manager or this blog Get Ready for the Mandatory Shift to E-invoicing in Belgium – The Clock is Ticking.

 

How Belgian companies should register

The Belgian Peppol authority, BOSA (FOD Beleid en Ondersteuning - SPF Stratégie & Appui), has defined Peppol Authority Specific Requirements (PASR) for its area of application, according to which companies must first and at least register as a participant in the Peppol network using their company number provided by the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE). After this initial registration, companies can register more participants using the VAT number or other identifiers, such as a SWIFT code or a GLN.

The steps are as follows:

Step 1: Mandatory registration:

First, register your company as a participant in the Peppol network using your company number with party ID type "0208".

0208: This party ID type represents the Belgian Crossroads Bank for Enterprises (CBE), which assigns unique party IDs for companies operating in Belgium, for example: 0441797980.

Here are the detailed steps on how to create a participant in SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: Creating a Participant for Your Company.

This creates a participant ID in the Peppol network consisting of the party ID type (it should be 0208 if it is your first participant) and the actual party ID for your company. As you can see, this participant ID is not given in advance by a government agency such as Peppol or a Peppol Access Point (AP) such as SAP.

Don’t forget to also register your company to receive electronic invoices: Registering Your Company to Receive Electronic Documents in the Peppol Network.

If your participant only exists in the Peppol network but is not yet registered to receive documents, you can send electronic documents through the Peppol network but can’t receive any.

Step 2: (Optional) additional registration:

In addition, you can register your company in the Peppol network using the company's VAT number, for example: BE0441797980, with the party ID type "9925". Other alternatives for the registration are the use of the generic ID ”0088” referring to the GLN or any other valid Peppol participant ID.

 

Migration from Hermes required

Hermes was an initiative by the Belgian government to advance electronic invoicing by enabling the receiving of electronic invoices in PDF format for receivers who are not (yet) able to process XML files.

All Belgian companies with a Belgian company number (party ID type: 0208) have been included by BOSA in the Hermes SMP (Service Metadata Publisher), which is part of the Peppol network.

If your company is ready to receive XML files, you must register your company using a Peppol Access Point like the cloud edition. However, if your company number is already used in Hermes SMP, your Peppol service provider needs to migrate it to the SMP of the Peppol Access Point. After this migration, you can then register your company number in the Peppol network as described in the previous section.

Support for SAP customers

If you are using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition as Peppol service provider, SAP migrates your company number for you from Hermes SMP to the SMP of SAP. To initiate the migration, create a customer case in SAP for Me with the title "MTCI migration required by Hermes SMP" under the component "LOD-LH-DRC-PAP". For other concerns regarding the electronic invoicing process, you can also submit a customer case under the component “CA-GTF-CSC-EDO-BE”.

 

 

I hope this blog was useful for you! You can leave a comment here or continue browsing our community for more blogs on SAP Document and Reporting Compliance topics.

entry.title: Customizing Your PDF with the Categories of Class A Invoices
entry.content:
Hello!  

In this blog, we will walk you through the steps of designing the new PDF templates using Adobe LiveCycle to remain compliant with R.G. N° 5762/2025 and R.G. N°5764/2025 for Argentina. For more information, see Changes: New Class A invoice categories and withholding regime on the Regulatory Change Manager.

If you carry out sales, work placements or provision of services in Argentina using print character M for VAT-registered taxpayers, according to resolution R.G. N° 5762/2025 and R.G. N°5764/2025, as of December 1, 2025, you must replace the existing class M invoices with the new categories of Class A invoices: 

Categories of Class A Invoices 

Description 

What you need to do 

Standard Class A 

For taxpayers meeting all fiscal and solvency requirements 

Nothing 

Class A with legend “OPERACIÓN SUJETA A RETENCIÓN” 

For taxpayers who do not meet certain requirements 

You design a new PDF template 

Class A with legend “PAGO EN CBU INFORMADA” 

For taxpayers who may not meet solvency criteria, requiring payments to be made to a specific, declared bank account (CBU) 

You design a new PDF template 

Prerequisites: 

  • You have Adobe LiveCycle Designer on your computer and know how to design forms with this tool.  
  • You have assigned the Extensibility (SAP_CORE_BC_EXT) authorization role for your user.  

Procedure: 

1. Access the Maintain Form Templates (F1434) app.  

2. Go to the Predelivered Templates tab and search for the following PDF form:  

Document Type: 

Print Char A, B, E 

Form Template Name: 

EDO_AR_PRINT 

Data Source: 

EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03 

3. Open the form template and select Download.  

4. Extract the downloaded ZIP file and open the .xdp file in the Adobe Livecycle Desginer.  

5. In the Adobe LifeCycle Designer, choose the Master Pages tab.   

6. From the Object Library, drag and drop a Text onto the PageType box of your PDF. (Note: We suggest placing the Text on the bottom left corner of the PageType box.)  

7. On the Hierarchy tab, select the new field (default name Text1) and open the context menu (right-click or press Shift+F10). Choose Rename, type Legenda, and press Enter.  

8. Edit the new Legenda text. Insert the respective text value: “PAGO EN CBU INFORMADA” or “OPERACIÓN SUJETA A RETENCIÓN”. 

9. On the Hierarchy tab, select the content field. 

10. After selecting the content field, open the Script Editor (default shortcut Ctrl+Shift+F5) and insert the following Javascript logic to configure Legenda field:  

if (this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.var_PrintChar").rawValue == 'A' ) { 
  this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "visible"; 
} else { 
this.resolveNode("sfHeader.content.Legenda").presence = "hidden"; 
}

11. Save and name your template. 

12. Access the Maintain Form Templates (F1434) app. 

13. On the Custom Templates tab, choose New. Create a custom template for your form by making the following settings:  

  • Form Template Name: Enter a name for your form template.  
  • Language: Select the language of your form template.  
  • Select Form Template File: Upload the file that you've created in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.  
  • Data Source: EDOC_AR_PRINT_SRV_03  
  • Form Type: Choose Standalone.  

14. Save your form template.  

15. In your configuration environment, use the search function to open the Configure Printing Form for eInvoice (103277) configuration activity and assign your custom form template to the relevant eDocument type and branch.   

And that's it!

You can now open the eDocument Cockpit and submit your document. The PDF form templates you created contain the new categories of Class A invoices for VAT-registered taxpayers. 

Was this post helpful? Leave a like (kudo) and share the content with your colleagues. Feel free to leave feedback, comments, or questions in the space below.    

For more information, go to Document and Reporting Compliance for Argentina on the SAP Help Portal and make sure to follow SAP Document and Reporting Compliance.    

 

Regards, 

João Pedro Braun Agnes & Pedro Brum

Regulatory Changes  
As part of the "Fiscalization 2.0" project and starting January 2026, the Croatian government is introducing B2B e-invoicing, e-reporting and fiscalization requirements. 

  • B2B/B2G e-invoicing: all businesses with VAT registration in Croatia need to send electronic invoices in the required format through an approved service provider.
  • Fiscalization: 
    • B2B/B2G invoices: issuer and receiver of e-invoices need to send the fiscal data of the invoice to authorities (digitally signed XML). 
    • B2C invoices: issuer of the e-invoice needs to send fiscal to authorities irrespective of payment method (currently required only for cash payments). 
  • E-reporting: in addition to invoicing data (fiscalization), the following reporting requirements need to be fulfilled: 
    • List of collected invoices (payment received), during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of outbound deliveries for which e-invoice could not be delivered, during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer.

entry.title: Setup communication for electronic submission of statutory reports.
entry.content:
In this blog post, I would like to provide a step-by-step guide to help you configure and integrate SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition or SAP S/4HANA Private Edition, specifically for electronic submission of statutory reports.

The communication and integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is available for a number of supported compliance reports per country / region (in both S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or On-Premise). Through the list(s) above, all already delivered supported compliance tasks which relates to Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition as supported submission types are relevant for communication setup and application configuration. 

This blog post will provide you with a walkthrough to help you navigate through the different configuration aspects within the SAP Help portal.  With simple setup steps and the configuration of your environment you will achieve proper communication of your business system with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and authentication to the tax authorities. 

The value of the integration between SAP S/4HANA business systems and SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition lies in the fact the setup of the various steps shown below need to be done only once for communication purpose – once done the main communication is then available for all reports.

Then, once you have completed specific application configuration for your reporting entity and communication settings specific for your report, a single click submits the report from your business system (through the application Run Statutory Reporting) and triggers the entire flow to electronic submit to the tax authority.

The configuration/set up required for each compliance report is depicted below:

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system:

  • Scope Item Activation (78L): Before starting, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition must have the communication scenario SAP_COM_0854 available for configuration of the communication in your business system.  If your report is listed on the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition supported compliance tasks with supported submission type as  Submitting Statutory Reports Using SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, Cloud Edition, please request activation of the scope item 78L (more information in the SAP Note 3387894).
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required, are available at:
      • setup instruction of the scope item 78L or 
      • Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA Cloud 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. This can be found by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission..

Configuration on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition business systems:

  • Implementing Required SAP Notes: Before starting, the SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition or On-Premise must contain the required implementation objects.  Each report includes these note details in the Supported Compliance Tasks by Country/Region table. To find this information, search by Country/Region and Task and the specific Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note. For example, if you search for United Kingdom and the task VAT Return, the Submission Implementation Overview SAP Note 3386362 appears in the Technical Information column.
  • Onboarding to the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition: If you have entitlement through your license then the next step is the Initial Setup of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • Connecting the Cloud Edition and the Business System: After onboarding, you must setup the Integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with your S/4HANA business system.
    • Communication Setup details, with all the information required for the backend setup, are available at: Integrating All Other Processes and Countries/Regions with SAP S/4HANA 
  • Reporting Configuration in the Business System and Cloud Edition: The final step is the specific configuration for your report.  Here you need to complete the following two main configurations: 
    • Configure your process-specific setting and authentication method for your reports per country/region in the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition (SAP BTP). Please verify it per your specific report at Process-Specific Setting.
    • Configure each statutory report by following the steps in the individual configuration documentation. You can find the configuration documentation in SAP S/4HANA by navigating to the links in the Reports column in the Reports Enabled for Electronic Submission.

I hope this guide can provide a comprehensive understanding of the configuration steps and where to find all relevant information for the configuration of the communication setup in SAP S/4HANA Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and SAP S/4HANA Cloud business systems.

Thank you and see you next time.

entry.title: SAP Document Reporting Compliance Angola
entry.content:
Angola Tax Authorities (Administracao Geral Tributaria) have published the technical specifications for their upcoming eInvoicing requirement, through the release of the Royal Decree (Decreto Executivo) n 683/25 published on 22nd of August 2025, which outlines the software data structure, electronic invoicing model, and technical and procedural specifications.

According to the Angola regulatory framework, taxpayers will need to use a certified electronic invoice software to generate and submit the electronic invoices to the Angola Tax Authority (AGT) in real time. The authenticity and integrity of electronically issued documents are ensured through a digital code defined by the AGT.

Angola Tax authorities will provide access to taxpayers and software producers to an eInvoicing portal (Portal do Parceiro), where specific authorizations will be granted to the parties; a testing phase will be provided. Whilst there was little indication that the deadline for large taxpayers would be delayed further to the 1st of October 2025, finally on 23rd of September, Angola Tax authorities announced a transitional period to adopt the mandate, lasting until the 1st of January 2026. Angola Tax authorities have also announced that the eInvocing portal will be made available to taxpayers by October 6th, 2025. From September 21st 2026, the obligation will be extended to all taxpayers.

As it is the case for the SAF-T mandate in Angola since 2020, the Tax authorities will require that the e-Invoicing software is certified with the Angola Tax authorities and allow for real-time transmission of information to the AGT; the certification will include the validation of the JSON for Invoices (Fatura), Credit Notes (Notas de Crédito), Receipts (Recibos) and Invoice-Receipts (Faturas-Recibo). The authenticity, integrity, and non-repudiation of electronically issued documents are ensured through a digital code defined by the AGT.

Taxpayers will need to enrol for E-invoicing through the AGT portal (Portal do Contribuinte) from where the certificates (Chave Publica e Chave Privada) will be available for download.

eInvoices will also need to have the specific series which needed to be communicated to AGT. Once the eInvoice is sent to AGT, AGT sends back a notification that the invoice was received and subsequently a message that the invoice is valid or invalid and, in case of the latter, the related reason. Once eInvoice is approved, taxpayer can send it to the recipient. AGT does not send the eInvoice to final recipient. eInvoices need to be capable of being printed in PDF including a QR code via the eInvocing software which will enable to check the invoice details.

Below picture depicts the Angola eInvoicing model:

Angola Tax authorities technical specifications for eInvoicing provide 7 different API REST services for integration with SIGT (Integrated Tax management system) and eInvocing softwares:

registerInvoice (registarFactura),

getStatus (obterEstado),

listInvoices (listarFacturas),

consultInvoice (consultarFactura),

requestSeries (solicitarSerie),

listSeries (listarSeries),

validateDocument (validarDocumento).   

Crimson Technology Partners has developed the SAP Document Reporting Compliance solution to respond to the eInvoicing mandate of Angola tax authorities. The solution is meeting the requirements of the Angola Tax authorities, and is ready to connect to the AGT platform, as soon as it is released.

SAP Document Reporting Compliance solutions by Crimson Technology partners respect the principle of consistent user experience across countries and uniform functionality across countries, without introducing any custom program or transaction code.

  • Self-billing scenario's

In this blog post, I would like to provide a step-by-step guide on how to configure and integrate the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition with SAP S/4HANA Cloud to electronically submit the VAT Return to the tax authorities. This blog will specifically cover the setup and configuration of the VAT return for the United Kingdom (GB) – a list of some other statutory reports and countries supported by SAP Document and Reporting Compliance can be found here.

Since the GB VAT Return process uses OAuth 2.0 and Authorization Code Flow, eliminating the need to maintain a username and password, only the VAT registration number and authorization code need to be maintained.

SAP S/4HANA provides the end-to-end process of recording your financial transactions, generating the VAT return and submitting the report electronically using the mandated API from HMRC in the correct JSON file format.
  • Sign in with your Government Gateway ID: This is your credential for accessing HMRC services. If you don’t have one, you can create a Government Gateway account: create a Government Gateway account.
  • Link your software to HMRC: SAP Document and Reporting Compliance will guide you through authorizing it to communicate with HMRC using your Government Gateway credentials.
  • To maintain your credentials for UK MTD, please go to the BTP app Manage Communication to External Parties. For UK MTD, this is your VAT registration number.

INITIAL AUTHORISATION

  • For the first submission, you will be prompted to enter your credentials in the HMRC portal. You will see a message asking if the SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition is authorized to access the HMRC portal. Please select "Yes" to generate and save a token in the Integration component in BTP for 18 months.

SUBSEQUENT SUBMISSIONS

  • For 18 months after the initial authorization, you will not need to enter a username and password for submissions. The GB_VAT_DCL report will be submitted as soon as the user selects the Submit button in the Fiori app Run Statutory Reports.
  • The access tokens need to be renewed every 18 months.  If the access tokens are not valid, at the time of submission, the user will be redirected to HMRC to renew the access tokens before submission can take place
